title: 114_s715
content: The Act titled "Military and Veterans Mental Health Provider Assessment Act of 2015" aims to improve mental health care provided by healthcare providers of the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Act requires all health care providers under the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs to receive training on recognizing and managing suicide risk every three years. Additionally, an evaluation of the implementation of clinical practice guidelines by mental health care providers must be conducted annually. The Act mandates training for healthcare providers in the Department of Defense and Veterans Affairs on suicide risk management. Evaluations of clinical practice guidelines by mental health providers must be done annually. The Secretaries will include these evaluations in employee performance assessments. A report on the mental health workforce and long-term care needs of Armed Forces members and veterans will be submitted to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The report will assess the number of mental health care providers in the Department of Defense and Veterans Affairs, including specialties like psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers, counselors, and therapists. It will also project the future need for these providers in both departments. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will jointly submit a plan to develop procedures for measuring mental health data within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. This plan will focus on compiling and assessing data related to outcomes of mental health care provided by the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs. The plan will focus on outcomes for mental health care provided by the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs, variations among different medical facilities, and barriers to implementing clinical practice guidelines. The term "Secretary concerned" refers to the Secretary of Defense for matters related to the Department of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for matters related to the Department of Veterans Affairs.
